Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Investigating Magma Ascent Rates and Eruption Styles at Kîlauea Volcano Using Diffusion Modeling of Element Zoning in Olivine Crystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern activity at Kîlauea Volcano (Hawai'i) has been dominated by effusive lava flows and spectacular fountaining events. However, recent work reveals a history of explosive eruptions, which killed large numbers of Hawaiians near the volcano's summit. These eruptions were drastically different compared to modern activity that has made Kîlauea seem like a relatively safe, quiet volcano. To understand and predict the frequency and style of volcanic eruptions at basaltic volcanoes like Kîlauea, knowing the amount of time magma resides within the volcano is crucial. This work will use the chemical composition of the most common mineral from Kîlauea (olivine) to determine how quickly magma ascends to the surface for explosive versus effusive eruptions. Comparing magma storage histories for different eruption types will contribute to understanding the long-term evolution of Kîlauea's magmatic plumbing system. Most importantly, this work will address how and when hazardous explosive eruptions can occur. The study will be conducted at Nanyang Technological University in collaboration with Dr. Fidel Costa Rodriguez, a leading researcher using olivine chemistry to calculate magma residence times at volcanoes around the world.

This project aims to (1) characterize magma residence times for two summit reservoirs at Kîlauea using recent effusive eruptions, and (2) evaluate the relationship between olivine residence time and eruption style by comparing diffusion histories from effusive and explosive eruptions. Major and minor (electron microprobe), plus trace (laser ablation mass spectrometry) element analyses of olivine crystals, in combination with crystallographic orientations (electron backscatter diffraction), will be used as model inputs to calculate residence times of olivine in eruptions of different styles and chemistries. Timescales will be determined using a finite difference diffusion modelling scheme. The volcanic implications will enhance understanding of the dynamic nature of Hawaiian volcanoes. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Background. Kilauea Volcano (Hawaii, USA) has had cycles of effusive (e.g. modern day) and explosive eruptions that can last many centuries. Because there have not been large explosive eruptions in modern times, the magmatic processes associated with this type of volcanic activity at Kilauea remain poorly understood. Determining the causes for effusive vs. explosive eruptions is imperative to assess hazard risks associated with each type. This work advances scientific understanding of contrasting eruption styles by using olivine chemistry to infer magma storage durations for explosive and effusive eruptions. It contributes to currently limited knowledge of the conditions leading up to these explosive eruptions. 

Project Outcomes. We analyzed the compositions of olivine crystals from eight units within the dominantly explosive Keanakakoi Tephra (1500-1823 CE). Major and minor elements (Si, Mg, Fe, Ni, Ca, Mn) were determined using electron microprobe analyses (EPMA) at the University of Hawaii and trace elements (Li, Na, Al, P, Ca, Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, and Ga) were analyzed using laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) at the Earth Observatory of Singapore, Nanyang Technological University. Core-rim transects of major, minor, and trace elements in chemically zoned olivine were collected and fit with a 1D finite difference diffusion model. These models were used to calculate timescales of magma storage and characterize histories of magma mixing and differentiation. Using preliminary results, we can compare storage histories with eruptive style (e.g. effusive vs. explosive) and begin to characterize the nature of Kilauea’s crustal magma reservoir system during these contrasting periods.

Broader Impacts

During the grant period we: (1) gained a better understanding of explosive eruptions at Kilauea, which can adversely influence the quality of life for nearby communities; (2) gained insights into reservoir re-assembly during a low magma supply period after caldera collapse; (3) increased international scientific cooperation through collaboration and utilization of facilities in Singapore; (4) disseminated preliminary results of the work through a presentation at the 2015 American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting; (5) presented preliminary results to peers at the University of Hawaii through a Graduate Seminar; and (6) gained professional development in lab training and analysis techniques for an underrepresented minority (women) in a facility that is unavailable at the University of Hawaii. Exposure to research in Singapore paved the way for new ideas for future work, both short- and long-term and provided personal development toward becoming more equipped to be an independent researcher.
